#Text=Erongo
#Text=Erongo is a region in eastern central Namibia .
#Text=Cities
#Text=, a mining town in the middle of the Namib Desert
#Text=, a coastal holiday town , famous for its angling opportunities
#Text=, a small town halfway between the capital Windhoek and the coast of the Atlantic
#Text=, a small town in the northeast of the region
#Text=, a coastal town and holiday destination with plenty of German colonial architecture
#Text=, Namibia 's most important harbour town
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=, a mountain massif that contains Namibia 's highest mountain , the Königstein , as well as San rock art , with the White Lady the most famous of it
#Text=The northern part of the Namib-Naukluft National Park
#Text=, a group of inselbergs rising from the Namib Desert
#Text=Understand
#Text=Erongo is situated on the Atlantic Ocean and has domestic borders with Hardap in the south , Khomas in the southeast , Otjozondjupa in the northeast , and Kunene in the north .
#Text=Most of its area is desert — rocky north of the Kuiseb River and sandy south of it .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Due to the scarcity of other options , most travellers will arrive by car .
#Text=The major highway in the region is the Trans-Kalahari Highway ( B2 ) that leads from Walvis Bay to Okahandja .
#Text=By air
#Text=Walvis Bay has a regional airport with scheduled flights to the capital Windhoek , and to Cape Town in South Africa .
#Text=By train
#Text=There is a train service from Windhoek to Walvis Bay via Karibib , Usakos , Arandis and Swakopmund .
#Text=It runs a few times a week during the night .
#Text=The train is predominantly for freight , with only one or two passenger cars , and it stops at every tree rock , as there are few trees in the desert .
#Text=But the 11-hour trip is cheap and safe , and safes a night of accommodation .
#Text=Bring a sleeping bag ; the desert is cold at night .
#Text=By public transport
#Text=Between towns you can catch a minibus .
#Text=Karibib , Usakos , Arandis and Swakopmund have local shared taxis that can take you around .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The B2 highway is tarred and in very good condition , as is the C33 from Karibib to Otjiwarongo .
#Text=The C34 from Swakopmund to Terrace Bay is paved with a sand-salt mix .
#Text=It behaves like tar when it is dry , and like soap when it is wet , drive carefully .
#Text=The Bosua Pass on the C28 can be problematic when driven uphill ( from the coast inlands ) :
#Text=It starts off with patches of sand and layers of rock which have to be navigated very slowly in order not to damage the car , and it then becomes very steep for a few meters .
#Text=All other C-roads are gravel roads and in fair condition , easily passable with an ordinary sedan .
#Text=Other roads ( D-roads , F-roads , and those without letters or numbers ) tend to be rough , sandy , heavily corrugated , and will further deteriorate after rainfall .
#Text=Within the Namib-Naukluft National Park there are plenty of smaller tracks for which a permit is required .
#Text=See our our park article for details .
#Text=Most of these tracks require a 4x4 .
#Text=Farms are private properties .
#Text=Do n't drive onto a farm road , even if the gate is open , unless your destination is signposted there , or you intend to visit that farm .
#Text=If you open a farm gate to drive through , close it again .
#Text=See
#Text=seal colony , 44km north-west of Hentiesbay
#Text=, an area of unreal results of the erosion of the Swakop River , 25km east of Swakopmund .
#Text=The road there further extends to the Welwitschia Plains which contain one of the largest of these plants that exist .
#Text=The entire trip has roadside markers every now and then to explain selected plants , artefacts , and geological features .
#Text=The road is very rough and crosses the sandy Swakop .
#Text=You will feel sorry for your car .
#Text=If you do n't have nerves of steel , come in a 4x4 , or do the trip by joining one of the frequent organised tours that start in Swakopmund .
#Text=, one of the largest open-pit uranium mines in the world .
#Text=There is a guided tour every first Friday of the month , departing from Swakopmund .
#Text=The machinery shown is impressive , particularly for kids , but you are also forced to watch a boring PR movie .
#Text=Tickets at the Swakopmund Museum .
#Text=Do
#Text=Visit , an environmental research center for desert conditions .
#Text=The center holds an annual open day on which you will be shown around .
#Text=If you miss that one you might still contact them to ask if you are welcome .
#Text=All roads to Gobabeb require a permit for the Namib-Naukluft National Park
#Text=Sleep
#Text=Erongo is touristically well developed .
#Text=There is tourist accommodation in all towns and villages .
#Text=Stay safe
#Text=The Ugab riverbed in northern Erongo is inhabited by desert elephants .
#Text=If you are driving through it , remember that the area is theirs , not yours .
#Text=They certainly know it .
#Text=Do n't drive too close towards a herd of elephants .
#Text=10-15 m is close enough for good holiday pictures and will normally not put your party in danger .
#Text=Otherwise , the younger ones might play with your car , the older ones might get angry , either way your car might end upside down .
#Text=You 'll know that an elephant is angry when it shakes its head .
#Text=In this case , stay in the car , switch off the engine , and avoid all unnatural noise ( cell phone , camera , such things ) .
#Text=They will eventually walk away ; wait for this to happen instead of trying a daring escape .
#Text=Go next
#Text=The following regions of Namibia border with Erongo :
#Text=Hardap in the south
#Text=Khomas in the southeast
#Text=Otjozondjupa in the northeast
#Text=Kunene
#Text=in the north
